STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 19, 2025
Yulonda Shell
Vista Maria Open Residential
20651 W. Warren St.,
Dearborn Heights, MI, 48127-2622
Re: License #: CI820201487
SI #: 2025SIC0000148
Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000148
Special Investigation Intake Date: November 26, 2024
License #: CI820201487
Licensee Group Organization: Sisters of Good Shepherd
Licensee Designee: Megan Zambiasi
Chief Administrator: Yulonda Shell
Agency Name: Vista Maria Open Residential
Agency Address: 20651 W. Warren St.
Dearborn Heights, MI 48127-2622
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 12/05/2026
Capacity: 96
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Contact Method Contact Purpose
Date
11/22/2024 Email Documentation received or sent
11/24/2024 Email Documentation received or sent
11/25/2024 Face to Face, on-site Special Investigation Initiation
11/26/2024 Other Documentation received or sent
12/20/2024 Email Documentation received or sent
1/17/2025 Face to Face Interview
1/23/2025 Telephone Interview
1/24/2025 Telephone Interview
2/6/2025 Video Conference Other
2/10/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
2/14/2025 Email Other
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing adequate services, resulting in a large
number of youths going to the emergency department.
Investigation On 11/22/24 Complainant reported a concerning number of
youths from Vista Maria were dropped at local hospital emergency
departments within the last 48 hours. There is concern the agency
is not providing proper care and programming to prevent the youth
from needing care in the emergency department.
Interviews:
Chief Administrator, Rights Officer, and Quality Manager were
contacted on 11/22/24 by email to obtain the names of youth that
were seen at a hospital from 11/19/24-11/22/24.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth A stated that she felt the program was not helpful to her as
there were no independent livings skills being learned, due to staff
doing everything for them. Youth A stated they do not have any
group activities. Therapy was 1-2 times per week. Youth could
color or do word searches during their downtime on the unit, but
they did not have access to use the gym and could only go
outside to the courtyard occasionally. Youth A stated they were
not able to go on outings often, due to peer behaviors. However,
she stated they went on walks occasionally and would walk to the
on-campus boutique to shop. Youth A acknowledged some staff
were more active with youth than others. Youth A stated if youth
were harming themselves, attacking staff, threatening suicide, or
breaking items to hurt themselves, staff would try to deescalate
the situation and talk to the youth about what is bothering them.
Staff also suggest other activities they can do such as puzzles and
games. If nothing works, then a supervisor would make the
decision to call the police to help. If the police came, they would
2

usually take the youth to the hospital for a few hours. Then the
youth return to the facility. Staff would always go to the hospital
with youth.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth B reported attending school daily and therapy weekly.
Youth on the unit also participated in groups that work on self-
reflection, discussing concerns, motivating self and others.
Groups were supposed to be twice per day, but that did not
always happen, due to peer behaviors. Youth B stated there were
volunteer groups that came in to do activities such as skill building
and watching movies. The Dream Realized through
Education/Empowerment and Mentoring (DREAM) group taught
independent living skills, interview skills and social skills. Youth B
felt the program was doing a good job helping her learn how to be
on her own eventually. However, some peers would be upset at
staff for trying to get them to participate. Some peers were also
upset with Youth B for listening to staff and being respectful and
participating in activities. Youth B stated some peers caused
trouble when they did not want to participate in activities and did
not have anything else to do. Youth B felt there should be more
consequences for youth that cause problems. Police were called
to the facility on occasion. Some supervisors called more than
others. Supervisors would call the police if a youth went truant,
self-harmed, or assaulted staff. Staff would talk to youth and work
the problem out but would call the police if necessary. Police then
took the youth to the hospital. Staff followed the police and stayed
at the hospital with youth. Youth then returned to the facility.
Overall, Youth B felt there were some very good staff that provide
a lot of support.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth C stated she did not like being at the facility as staff always
corrected her. Youth C identified activities on the unit such as
cooking, movies, gym, games, crafts, and groups about making
good decisions. Youth C stated they were sometimes unable to do
activities when peers on the unit acted out and pulled staff
attention away from the schedule. Staff would try to talk with the
youth, problem solve and deescalate. However, police were
sometimes called to assist in transporting a youth that needed to
go to the hospital due to out of control behavior.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth D stated they attended therapy weekly and found it to be
helpful. Youth D reported that groups were held daily, but she did
not always participate as it was usually an activity she did not
3

enjoy. Youth D reported she was able to make phone calls to
family every day, and she was able to draw or read daily. Youth D
stated there were no organized, recreational activities available to
youth and they sat on the unit all day, “doing nothing”. Youth D
indicated Journey To Success (JTS) was a group of people that
came to the unit to do activities and independent living skills.
However, JTS was no longer occurring. Youth D stated she
wished they did more activities and included exercise or
movement daily. Youth D reported that some youth were able to
go on outings to go shopping. Youth D felt this was favoritism by
staff and not based on behavior, although she could not explain
why. Youth D wished there were more outings and fun activities
planned. However, she acknowledged that behavior of youth
impacted staff ability to do things. Peer behavior would cause staff
to be busy deescalating youth, rather than doing activities with the
other youth. Youth D reported police were called to the facility
when youth were physically acting out and creating weapons to
hurt people. Staff would talk with the youth and remove dangerous
items. Police would be contacted for assistance. Youth D also
observed staff to call the police when a youth was suicidal, self-
harming, or swallowing things, and they needed to go to the
hospital to be evaluated. Staff would try to talk to youth and
redirect them, but that did not always work. Youth D stated police
always took youth to the hospital and staff followed in another car.
When asked what the facility could change to better meet the
youth needs, Youth D stated they needed to plan more outings to
encourage the youth to have good behavior to earn those things.
Chief Administrator contacted DCWL via email on 12/20/24,
outlining activities planned for youth during their holiday break
from school. Activities included Science Technology Engineering
Math (STEM) activities, basketball, holiday party, Lego activities,
movies, and a content creator workshop.
Rights Officer was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/15/25. Rights Officer reported the facility was partnering with
Wayne County Community Mental Health to complete on-site
screenings for Wayne MDHHS youth, to determine if they are in
need of short-term hospitalization. On 1/21/25 Rights Officer
clarified via email that JTS was a program within Vista Maria that
organized events such as groups and dances, where instructors
were brought to campus. Recently they had a hair show and a
family movie day for the youth. Dream Realized through
Education/Empowerment and Mentoring (DREAM) was a group
that was part of JTS that also offers group activities to youth on
campus. Heart Warmers was a spiritual group that youth could
4

participate in on Sundays. Rights Officer confirmed that all of
these groups remain active on campus.
Quality Manager was contacted via email on 1/23/25 regarding
the plans to revamp services on campus. Quality Manager
reported there was a work group developed by the Activities &
Academic Support Manager. The work group was reviewing
current activities and creating new programming activities to
engage the youth. Previously the facility contracted with outside
partners for activities. There was also a restructured client
advisory board, similar to a student council, to provide youth with
more of a voice in decisions that were made. Youth would be able
to bring any issues, concerns, wishes, requests to the group for
discussion and decision making.
Activities & Academic Support Manager (AASM) was contacted
via email on 1/23/25. AASM outlined the following items available
to youth on campus: afterschool activities include but are not
limited to, expressive therapies such as yoga, dance movement
therapy, music therapy, art therapy, physical activity and
nutritional health education. Academic mentoring and tutoring are
supported through the DREAM program as it connects each youth
with mentors who are successful in their career paths and provide
supports by focusing on their education and future career goals. In
addition, the activity team provides programing that creates a safe
environment to strengthen coping skills, promote social
connections, and support healthy self-esteem and confidence
through creative self-care strategies. Lastly, the Transition to
Independence Process (TIP) model, supports the youth in areas
of education, employment, social skills, relationships and health,
and life skills.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Staff 1 reported the youth engaged in activities such as dance,
music, drawing, crossword puzzles, and some organized group
activities. Staff 1 stated some youth chose not to participate in
activities. Some youth were also not able to participate due to
behavioral issues. Staff 1 stated that police were called to the
facility if youth were having constant dangerous behaviors that
could not be redirected. When youth were angry or frustrated, staff
would talk to them and do things to get their mind off the problem.
However, when youth were in ‘attack mode’, self-harming,
attacking/injuring people, destroying property to harm others, and
could not be deescalated, the police were called. The police
sometimes transported youth to the hospital to be evaluated when
they were self-harming, having suicidal thoughts, or injuring
5

themselves or others. The decision to call the police was made by
a supervisor or team leader. Staff then followed the police to the
hospital to sit with the youth while they were evaluated.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Staff 2 noted she was a new employee. Staff 2 stated youth
attended school, had group, completed chores, and watched tv or
did other activities. Group mostly consisted of the youth getting
together to talk about issues. Sometimes they would color or do
worksheets. Staff 2 did not observed youth to have time outside,
other than using the outdoor courtyard. Staff 2 did not go to the
gym with youth. Police could be called to the unit if a youth was
violent and attacking staff. Before the police were called, staff
worked to keep the youth safe by removing items, talking to the
youth, calling for additional staff assistance, and trying to calm the
youth. If a supervisor or team leader decided the police needed to
be involved, they would make the call. Police typically took the
youth to the hospital if they were self-harming, attacking someone,
or had injuries. Staff followed the police to the hospital to sit with
the youth.
Therapist 1 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 1
reported youth participated in therapy 1-2 times per week. Youth
also attended group therapy, expressive therapies, recreational
therapy through JTS. JTS includes STEM activities, mentoring
and educational tutoring. Youth also received occupational
therapy, psychiatric, medical, and family engagement services.
While on their unit youth were able to play games, participate in
art, watch television, and participate in groups. Regarding police
or hospital involvement, their services could be needed if a youth
was highly escalated to an extent that it was a safety concern, and
they are unable to regulate themselves or be deescalated.
Sometimes physical intervention could be used, but that was not
always safe, especially with a youth that was self-harming or
physically aggressive. The unit manager, clinical director or head
consulting psychiatrist made the determination if youth should be
sent to the hospital. Therapist 1 stated the facility began working
with Wayne County Community Mental Health to complete
assessments at the facility rather than visiting the hospital.
Therapist 1 has not had any experience with this service at this
time.
Therapist 2 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 2
reported that youth were offered activities such as games, art,
gym, dance class, and cooking class. Therapist 2 believed youth
indicated they were not doing as many activities lately due to
6

some programs being revamped. Some activities could also be
restricted if the youth was physically aggressive. For example,
instead of using colored pencils that may be sharp, a youth could
be given crayons to draw. In addition to activities, youth also
attended individual and family therapy, and occupational therapy.
In therapy they worked on triggers and warning signs, coping
skills, thinking/feeling, and discuss problem solving. Regarding
hospitalization and police contact, Therapist 2 reported that youth
could be escorted to the hospital by police if they had continued
escalated physical aggression, self-harming, or suicidal behavior
that staff are unable to reduce after multiple attempts to help the
youth self-regulate. The clinical supervisor and clinical director
must make the determination if assistance is to be called.
Therapist 2 also reported that the facility began a partnership with
Wayne County CMH, where CMH staff will complete on-site
assessments to determine if a youth was eligible for short term
hospitalization.
Therapist 3 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 3
reported that youth at the facility were offered therapy, psychiatrist
appointments, occupational therapy, DREAM, life skills, leadership
skills, and afterschool activities such as sports, art, and dance.
Youth attended therapy twice per week on a flexible schedule that
works best for the youth. Regarding police and hospital services,
youth were sent to the hospital when there was a suicide attempt
or AWOL. Youth may also be sent if they were highly aggressive
toward others, and staff have been unsuccessful at calming them
down. The police may be called to safely escort youth to the
hospital upon approval by the clinical supervisor and director.
Therapist 3 noted the facility was also working with Wayne County
CMH, as they would go on site to complete assessments for
youth, rather than sending the youth to the hospital.
Therapist 4 was interviewed by phone on 1/24/25. Therapist 4
stated that youth on campus participated in individual therapy,
group work, JTS activities, DREAM program, Alcoholics
Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous, structured activities with
volunteer groups, occupational therapy, religious services, and
receive support from youth counselors. JTS had pro-social life
skills, games, yoga, dance, sports and art. DREAM offered life
skills, vocational training, exercise and mentorship. On the unit,
youth were able to participate in art, games, movies, crafts,
activities in the courtyard, and go on outings in the community.
These activities may be modified at times, due to youth behavioral
or safety issues. Therapist 4 stated youth received at least one
hour of therapy per week, which may be broken up into smaller
7

sessions, depending on the youth. Regarding police or hospital
involvement, Therapist 4 stated police may be called to campus if
youth had violent behaviors and attacked staff or peers. Police
would not be called until after staff made several efforts to
deescalate the youth. A supervisor, clinical director and the
psychiatrist would determine when police would be called to
campus. Generally, this decision was made when a youth needed
to be evaluated, but staff did not feel they could safely transport
the youth. Therapist 4 stated that she had some experience with
the new process of having Wayne County Community Mental
Health complete an assessment on-site, in lieu of going to the
hospital. The assessment was well done and determined the
youth needed inpatient hospitalization. However, there was not a
placement available. The service was helpful, but not as helpful as
they hoped.
Documents Reviewed:
• Vista Maria Program Statement updated 3/22/2024: Direct
Program Services: “weekly individual therapy, monthly
family and group therapy, sensory integration approaches,
expressive therapies, group counseling focused on
intervention, non-violent crisis interventions approaches,
community outings, daily recreation, after-school activities,
nursing services, mentoring, life skills education, family
visitation and phone call opportunities, transportation to
home visits when appropriate, family engagement events,
and aftercare services for six months after discharge.
Contracted services include on-campus education,
psychiatric and psychological evaluations, medical, optical,
and dental examinations.”
• “Youth log of daily expectations”: Staff must indicate if
youth met expected behavior standards for the following
activities: social skills, peer interaction, school/study time,
personal care, group participation, recreation participation,
room care/chores, healthy eating, appropriate dress,
effective coping skills, safe behavior/transport.
• ‘Emergency Psychiatric Care” policy dated July 2014.
• If client is in imminent danger of harming herself or
others, supervisor/team leader/staff contacts 911.
• If the situation is serious but there is no imminent
danger, arrange for staff or private ambulance
transport to appropriate psychiatric crisis
assessment center.
• Staff should not transport an uncontrollable client. If
the situation requires it, the supervisor should call
911 for assistance.
8

• “Police on Campus” policy dated March 2021:
• When a situation arises that threatens the health,
safety, and welfare of our clients or staff and that is
beyond our ability to control, the police department
should be contacted for assistance.
• The shift supervisor or designated will contact the
police via 911.
• Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily
phone calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime”
with volunteer group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost
Voices Concert, town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace
Up Detroit, Pet Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah
Foundation, holiday decorating, and youth health fair.
• A review of MiSACWIS incident reports for the facility was
completed to confirm the youth that visited the hospital from
11/19-24-11/22/24: Youth A.
• Case record review for Youth A
• Youth A was placed at the facility on 9/11/24.
• Incident report dated 11/19/24- Youth A refused to
follow directions, began swearing at staff threatening to
assault them. Youth A threatened to pull the fire alarm
stating that she knew staff could not stop her. Youth A
began hitting windows and walls, pulling screws out of
walls and doors. Youth A threatened to cut people. Staff
verbally redirected. Youth A kicked staff and broke a
window. Youth A pulled a metal piece out of the window
and put it in her mouth. Youth A was directed to take
metal out of her mouth, but refused. Youth A tried to get
a piece of glass, but staff blocked her. Staff attempted
to redirect. Youth A continued to try to get the glass.
Police were called and escorted Youth A to the hospital.
Staff followed. Youth A returned to the facility shortly
after.
• Updated service plan dated 9/18/24- Youth A has
extensive history of suicidal ideation, defiant behaviors,
truancy, physical aggression, assaulting staff and peers,
self-harm, threats to police, refusal to follow directions,
and substance use. Youth A was diagnosed with post-
traumatic stress disorder, oppositional defiance
disorder, attention deficit disorder, and general anxiety
order. Youth A received daily recreational therapy with
includes walking, sports, games, group and individual
activities. Youth A is encouraged to participate in
trauma survival skills, self-care, positive approaches to
address adaptive behavior offered at the facility.
9

• Therapist 5 provided documentation to verify that Youth
A has consistently attended weekly therapy.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. One youth were sent to the
hospital during the identified timeframe. The youth was sent to the
hospital in accordance with agency policy and there was no
indication youth were not provided with services.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Recreational activities, equipment, and supplies; swimming
Title restriction.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136
Section (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and outdoor
Description recreational activities designed to meet the residents’ needs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing sufficient activities for youth.
Investigation During interviews, youth and staff reported there were several
activities available to youth in the program. However, Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported that
activities did not always occur. Youth and staff indicated there was
increased acting out behavior when activities did not occur, or
when youth were placed on wing restriction from activities. Youth
and staff reported concerns that the agency’s behavior
management/reward system was not effective. Youth and staff
reported concerns that staff spend too much time deescalating
certain youth and therefore not completing activities with other
youth.
During interviews Youth A and Staff 2 reported youth do not have
opportunities to participate in outdoor activities.
Activities & Academic Support Manager provided
documentation of several indoor activities made available for
youth. However, no outdoor activities were identified.
During a call on 2/6/25, Chief Administrator and Quality
Manager reported that youth participate in outdoor activity when
the weather permits. However, they were unsure if there was a
schedule of outdoor activities. They were asked to provide
documentation to show that youth were participating in outdoor
activity on a regular basis. In subsequent emails on 2/10/25 and
10

2/14/25, Quality Manager reported they did not have any
documentation to verify this request.
Documents Reviewed:
Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily phone
calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime” with volunteer
group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost Voices Concert,
town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace Up Detroit, Pet
Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah Foundation, holiday
decorating, and youth health fair.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as youth reported being
unable to participate in activities due to peer behavior, or not
having any activities available to them while on wing restriction.
Youth also reported they are not able to engage in outdoor activity
and the agency did not have any documentation to verify outdoor
activities occur with youth.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was provided regarding staff consistency. Youth
reported that some staff engage with youth more than others. Staff
engagement with youth should be consistent and ongoing. A daily
schedule and occasional monitoring by supervisors may help
address this concern. Consultation was offered regarding youth
behavior on units that disrupt the daily activities. When disruptive
behavior is ongoing and prohibiting other youth from their daily
activities, efforts should be made to continue activities with youth
in another area, away from the disruption. Not only would this be a
positive step for the other youth, but it would also take away the
acting out youth’s power to control the daily activity of the unit.
Additionally, for youth placed on restriction that are missing
activities, staff should continue to focus on encouraging the youth
to reduce behaviors in order to re-join the group. This may help
alleviate the youth’s feeling that wing restriction is never ending.
Lastly, inclusion of ideas from some restricted youth in the client
advisory board would be a great way to determine some activities
that restricted youth may be interested in, to help them increase
engagement in the program.
Conclusion Violation Established
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
_ ______________February 18, 2025_______________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 19, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12
